January 12, 2003: Fiction
THE LOVELY BONES, by Alice Sebold. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A 14-year-old girl
looks down from heaven as she describes what happens in the aftermath of her
kidnapping and murder.
FOUR BLIND MICE, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) Detective Alex
Cross and his partner, John Sampson, try to prove that one of Sampson's oldest
friends has been framed for murder.
PREY, by Michael Crichton. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) In the Nevada desert, a team
of scientists tries to undo an experiment involving nanoparticles — moleculesized
robots — that has gone disastrously wrong.
SKIPPING CHRISTMAS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $14.95.) A husband and
wife discover that their decision to forgo Christmas comes with consequences.
BY THE LIGHT OF THE MOON, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $26.95.) A young
man who has been injected with a mysterious substance finds himself drawn to
crime scenes immediately before the crimes occur.
HORNET FLIGHT, by Ken Follett. (Dutton, $26.95.) In 1941, as the Luftwaffe is
shooting down R.A.F. bombers, a young Dane stumbles upon a German
installation whose secrets he must try to convey to England.
RED RABBIT, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $28.95.) In the early 1980's, when he is a
C.I.A. novice, Jack Ryan acts to thwart a Soviet plot against the pope.
ANSWERED PRAYERS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) A sophisticated
New Yorker who has applied to law school against her husband's wishes finds the
possibility of true love with a childhood friend.
THE CHRISTMAS TRAIN, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $19.95.) A disillusioned
journalist goes on a journey of self-discovery during the holidays.
FROM A BUICK 8, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) An abandoned 1954 Buick
Roadmaster turns out to be a conduit to another, evil dimension.
THE LAST JIHAD, by Joel C. Rosenberg. (Forge/ Tom Doherty, $24.95.) A Wall
Street wizard, close friend of the president of the United States, must help protect
the country from nuclear attacks by Iraq.
REVERSIBLE ERRORS, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) A
corporate lawyer agrees to represent a man who is on death row for having
committed a triple murder in Kindle County in 1991.
NIGHTS IN RODANTHE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $22.95.) After her
husband leaves her for someone younger, a 45-year-old woman finds romance.
January 12, 2003
Non-Fiction
BUSH AT WAR, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) Behind the scenes
at the White House as the president and his advisers responded to the 9/11
attacks.
PORTRAIT OF A KILLER, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $27.95.) The crime
novelist presents evidence that the artist Walter Sickert was Jack the Ripper.
LEADERSHIP, by Rudolph W. Giuliani with Ken Kurson. (Miramax/Hyperion,
$25.95.) The former mayor of New York discusses what it takes to be a leader and
addresses subjects like the crime rate and 9/11.
JOURNALS, by Kurt Cobain. (Riverhead, $29.95.) A selection of drawings, lyrics
and other writings left behind by the lead singer of Nirvana, who committed suicide
A LONG WAY FROM HOME, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The
NBC News anchor recalls growing up in South Dakota in the 1940’s and 50’s.
MY LOSING SEASON, by Pat Conroy. (Nan A. Talese/ Doubleday, $27.95.) The
novelist remembers his last year playing basketball, as a point guard for the
Citadel in 1966-67.
STUPID WHITE MEN, by Michael Moore. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The man behind "Roger & Me" takes aim at our "nation of idiots."
THE CONQUERORS, by Michael Beschloss. (Simon & Schuster, $26.95.) How
Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman worked to ensure the destruction of
Hitler's Germany.
LIVE FROM NEW YORK, by Tom Shales and James Andrew Miller. (Little, Brown,
$25.95.) An oral history of "Saturday Night Live."
SANDY KOUFAX, by Jane Leavy. (HarperCollins, $23.95.) A biography of the
great pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers.
I MAY BE WRONG BUT I DOUBT IT, by Charles Barkley. Edited by Michael
Wilbon. (Random House, $22.95.) Observations by the former N.B.A. star and
current basketball commentator.
LET'S ROLL! by Lisa Beamer with Ken Abraham. (Tyndale, $24.99.) A memoir by
the wife of Todd Beamer, one of the passengers on United Flight 93, the hijacked
jet that crashed in Pennsylvania on Sept. 11.
LET FREEDOM RING, by Sean Hannity. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $25.95.)
The conservative commentator surveys domestic and foreign issues after Sept.
